bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this regulation:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: Act means the Water Sustainability Act;
annular space means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an open space between the outside of the casing of a well and the surrounding geological formation, or
an open space between 2 or more casings in the same well;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: backfill materials means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: uncontaminated natural geological materials,
uncontaminated drill cuttings, or
uncontaminated non-toxic synthetic materials;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: borehole means a drilled geotechnical well, other than a test pit, that is intended to remain in service for a period of not more than 30 days after construction;
casing means the piping or tubing installed in a well to support the sides of the well and includes production casing and surface casing;
casing stick-up, in relation to a well, means the length of the production casing in the well that is above

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the surface of the ground adjacent to the well, or
the floor of the well sump, pump house or well pit;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: closed-loop geoexchange well means a well, other than an open-loop geoexchange well, used or intended to be used for the purpose of heat exchange in a closed-loop geoexchange system in which there is no transfer of water between an aquifer and the well;
closure plug means the sealant placed in the uppermost portion of a well that is being decommissioned;

develop, in relation to a well, means remove from an aquifer the fine sediment and other organic or inorganic material that immediately surrounds the well screen, the drill hole or the intake area at the bottom of the well;
dewatering well means a well used or intended to be used for the purpose of diverting or conveying groundwater by pumping in order to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: facilitate an excavation,
stabilize an area of land, a building or any other improvement, or
reduce water pressure in a geological formation;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: drainage well means a well used or intended to be used for the purpose of diverting or conveying groundwater by the force of gravity and without pumping in order to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: facilitate an excavation,
stabilize an area of land, a building or any other improvement, or
reduce water pressure in a geological formation;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: drive shoe means a commercially-manufactured, forged or tempered steel sleeve with a cutting edge attached to the bottom of a drive pipe or casing to act as a cutting edge or protector for the lower edge of the drive pipe or casing during drilling;
excavated well means a well, commonly known as a dug well, excavated by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: digging in unconsolidated materials using manual or mechanical methods, or
blasting in consolidated materials;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: flood debris means material, natural or otherwise, that is relocated by the movement of flood waters;

foreign matter means a thing, matter or substance described in section 59 (1) (a) to (g) [prohibition on introducing foreign matter into well] of the Act and includes the substances prescribed under section 2 of this regulation;
former regulation means the Ground Water Protection Regulation, B.C. Reg. 299/2004;
injection well means a well used or intended to be used for the purpose of conveying water into a geological formation with the aid of a well pump;
liner means piping or tubing installed in a well to protect the well pump or other works in the well from damage;
modify means make a change, other than an alteration, to a well or wellhead;

open-loop geoexchange well means a water supply well that is used or intended to be used for the purpose of heat exchange in an open-loop geoexchange system in which there is a transfer of water between an aquifer and the well;
permanent means,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in relation to a well, a well that is intended to be in service for a period of more than 90 days after construction, and
in relation to a well pump, a well pump that is intended to remain installed in a well for a period of more than 90 days after installation;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: pitless adapter means a mechanical device attached to a casing for the underground conveyance of water to or from a well;
pumping test means a flow test of a well in which the well is pumped and the quantity of water pumped, pumping water levels and recovery water levels are measured

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to provide an estimate of the capacity of the well to produce groundwater, and
to assess aquifer characteristics;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: recharge well means a well used or intended to be used for the purpose of conveying water into a geological formation without the aid of a well pump and includes soakaway pits that are unfilled and cased;
register means a register of registered persons maintained by the comptroller, as described in section 7 [registers of well drillers and well pump installers], in respect of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: registered well drillers, or
registered well pump installers;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: registration number means,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in relation to a well driller, the registration number recorded for the well driller by the comptroller on the register of well drillers, and
in relation to a well pump installer, the registration number recorded for the well pump installer by the comptroller on the register of well pump installers;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: rehabilitate, in relation to a well, means use chemical, mechanical or physical methods to improve or restore the capacity of the well to produce groundwater;
remediation well means a well that is used or intended to be used for the purpose of groundwater remediation, including the removal or treatment of contaminants that have entered an aquifer;
screen assembly, in relation to a well, means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a screen in the well,
a closed bottom, and
any other related components, including a riser pipe, packer, screen blank or tail pipe, that are required for

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the method or type of installation of the screen, or
the nature of the geological formation;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: sealant means a sealing material or mixture of sealing materials that is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: less permeable than the surrounding geological formation to be sealed,
appropriate for the particular soil and water conditions, and
non-toxic and does not have an adverse impact on the quality of the groundwater in an aquifer or a well;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: shut-in pressure, in relation to a flowing artesian well, means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the water pressure after the artesian flow has been stopped, or
the height of the water above the top of the production casing or above the surface of the ground after the artesian flow has been stopped;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: sounding tube means a tube that enables the groundwater level in a well to be measured;

static water level, in relation to a well, means the distance from the top of the production casing or the surface of the ground to the groundwater level in the well, when the groundwater level is not affected by pumping activities in the well;
surface casing means a casing that surrounds the production casing of a well;
surface seal means a sealant that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is installed in the annular space around the outside of the outermost casing and between multiple casings, and
extends to or just below the surface of the ground;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: temporary means,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in relation to a well, a well that is intended to be in service for a period of not more than 90 days after construction, and
in relation to a well pump, a well pump that is intended to remain installed in a well for a period of not more than 90 days after installation;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: test pit means an excavated geotechnical well that is intended to remain in service for a period of not more than 30 days after construction;
unconsolidated aquifer means an aquifer composed of sediment, such as gravel or sand;

water supply well means a well used or intended to be used for the purpose of exploring for, diverting or using groundwater, and includes a water source well, but does not include a drainage well, dewatering well or remediation well;
well construction report means a report required under section 57 (1) [well reports] of the Act relating to the construction of a well;
well decommission report means a report required under section 57 (1) of the Act relating to the decommissioning of a well;
well identification report means a report required under section 55 (4) [well identification] of the Act relating to the identification of a well;
well pit means an excavated artificial opening in the ground, lined with concrete, metal or wood, that contains a wellhead that is below the surface of the ground;
well tag number means the file number assigned in the government's records to the records in relation to a particular well;
well yield test means a flow test of a well that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is conducted by airlifting, bailing or a similar method, and
provides an approximate estimate of the capacity of the well to produce groundwater.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In the Act and this regulation:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: flow test means a pumping test or a well yield test;
flowing artesian well means a well in which water, without the aid of a well pump,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: rises above the surface of the ground or the top of the casing, if any, and
flows, either continuously or periodically.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of sections 54 [attachment of well identification plates by owner of well supplying water supply system] and 63 [protection of water supply system wells from entry of foreign matter and physical damage], owner and water supply system have the same meaning as in section 55 of the Act.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The following matters or substances are prescribed for the purposes of section 59 (1) (f) [prohibition on introducing foreign matter into well] of the Act:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: paint and paint products;
liquid fuels;
fuel additives;
lubricants, other than water;
solvents, other than water;
herbicides and fungicides;
flood waters and flood debris.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The following artificial openings in the ground are excluded from the definition of "well" in section 1 [definitions] of the Act:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the following artificial openings made for the purpose of drainage:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: drains, including building perimeter drains, curtain drains, French drains and backfilled soakaway pits;
sumps in buildings that are part of the drainage systems of the buildings;
ditches or infiltration trenches of a shallow and linear nature;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prefabricated vertical drains, vertical strip drains, wick drains and sand drains made for the purpose of facilitating soil consolidation prior to building construction;
seismic relief holes, including stone columns and stone densification points, made for the purpose of dissipating excess water pressure caused by seismic activity;
drill holes made for the purpose of mineral exploration.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following are exempt from the requirements of this regulation and of Division 3 [Wells and Groundwater Protection] of Part 3 of the Act:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: water source wells that are used to divert deep groundwater in the subject area, as "deep groundwater" and "subject area" are defined in section 51 of the Water Sustainability Regulation, and from which wells deep groundwater is used for an oil and gas purpose in the subject area;
drainage wells;
horizontal closed-loop geoexchange wells that are less than 5 m deep;
test pits.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (1), the following provisions apply in relation to the wells referred to in that subsection:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Part 8 [Artesian Flow];
sections 74 (2) [decommissioning boreholes and test pits] and 80 [well decommission reports for flowing artesian wells];

sections 52 [controlling artesian flow during construction], 53 [controlling flowing artesian well], 57 (3) (b) [well reports in prescribed circumstances], 59 [prohibition on introducing foreign matter into well], 60 [remediation orders in relation to foreign matter in well] and 61 [wells on Crown land] of the Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of this regulation, each of the following is a class of well:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: water supply wells;
monitoring wells;
recharge wells;
injection wells;
dewatering wells;
remediation wells;
geotechnical wells;
closed-loop geoexchange wells.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of this regulation, each of the following is a subclass of the geotechnical well class:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: boreholes;
test pits.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Application of standards to well classes

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a well that is being changed to a different class, or the person responsible for changing the class of a well, as applicable, must ensure that the well meets the standards and requirements of the Act and this regulation that apply to the new class of well.

The person responsible for drilling or altering either of the following wells must ensure that the well meets the highest standards and requirements of the Act and this regulation for any class or subclass that apply in respect of either of the following wells:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a well that is drilled or altered so that the well is in more than one class or subclass of well;
a well the use or purpose of which is changed so that the well is in more than one class or subclass of well.

bcl:part.bcl:text: Well Drillers and Well Pump Installers

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Registers of well drillers and well pump installers
bcl:section.bcl:text: The comptroller must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: establish and maintain

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a register of well drillers who are authorized to operate in British Columbia, and
a register of well pump installers who are authorized to operate in British Columbia,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: include in the registers the following information in respect of each well driller and well pump installer:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: full name;
business contact information, including business name, if any, address, telephone number and, if available, email address and fax number;
the registration number issued by the comptroller and the date of registration;
a reference to any certificates of qualification held by the well driller or qualified well pump installer;
in the case of a well driller, the class of well driller assigned by the comptroller in accordance with section 9 [registration and classification of well driller],

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: make available to the public during normal business hours, or by posting on a publicly available website, a list of well drillers and well pump installers, which list may include any of the information set out in paragraph (b), and
remove from the register any person who

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: fails to meet a requirement for registration,
fails to maintain a requirement for registration, including any requirement for maintaining a certificate issued by another province or territory of Canada, or
is no longer actively working in Canada as a well driller or well pump installer.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Application for registration as well driller

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person may apply to the comptroller for registration as a well driller by completing and submitting an application in the form and with the content specified by the comptroller.
A prospective registrant described in subsection (1) must provide with an application proof satisfactory to the comptroller that the prospective registrant

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is an individual who is at least 19 years of age, and
holds, for the purposes of the definition of "well driller" in section 48 (1) [definitions] of the Act, one of the following prescribed qualifications:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a certificate of qualification as a Water Well Driller issued by SkilledTradesBC under the Skilled Trades BC Act;
a certificate of qualification as a Geoexchange Driller issued by SkilledTradesBC under the Skilled Trades BC Act;
a certificate of qualification as a Geotechnical/Environmental Driller issued by SkilledTradesBC under the Skilled Trades BC Act;
a certificate issued by another province or territory of Canada that is equivalent to a certificate referred to in subparagraph (i), (ii) or (iii);
a certificate as a Ground Water Drilling Technician issued by the Canadian Ground Water Association before April 26, 2013.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Registration and classification of well driller

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the comptroller approves a person's application under section 8 (1) to be registered as a well driller, the comptroller must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: classify the person as being in one or more of the following classes, based on the comptroller's assessment of the person's qualifications:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a water well driller, if the person has a qualification described in section 8 (2) (b) (i), (iv) or (v);
a geoexchange driller, if the person has a qualification described in section 8 (2) (b) (ii) or (iv);
a geotechnical / environmental driller, if the person has a qualification described in section 8 (2) (b) (iii) or (iv),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: add the person to the register of well drillers, and
issue an identification card to the person that includes reference to the classification of that person under paragraph (a) as one or more of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a water well driller;
a geoexchange driller;
a geotechnical / environmental driller.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Promptly after this regulation comes into force, the comptroller must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: classify every person who was registered in the register of qualified well drillers under the former regulation immediately before the date this regulation comes into force as all of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a water well driller;
a geoexchange driller;
a geotechnical / environmental driller,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: ensure that every person classified as a well driller under paragraph (a) is added to the register of well drillers, and
issue an identification card to every person classified as a well driller under paragraph (a) that includes reference to the classification of that person as all of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a water well driller;
a geoexchange driller;
a geotechnical / environmental driller.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Application for registration as well pump installer

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person may apply to the comptroller for registration as a well pump installer by completing and submitting an application in the form and with the content specified by the comptroller.
A prospective registrant described in subsection (1) must provide with an application proof satisfactory to the comptroller that the prospective registrant

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is an individual who is at least 19 years of age, and
holds, for the purposes of the definition of "well pump installer" in section 48 (1) [definitions] of the Act, one of the following prescribed qualifications:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a certificate of qualification as a Well Pump Installer issued by SkilledTradesBC under the Skilled Trades BC Act;
a certificate issued by another province or territory of Canada that is equivalent to a certificate referred to in subparagraph (i);
a certificate as a Ground Water Pump Technician issued by the Canadian Ground Water Association before April 26, 2013.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the comptroller approves a person's application under section 10 (1) to be registered as a well pump installer, the comptroller must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: add the person to the register of well pump installers, and
issue an identification card to the person that identifies that person as a well pump installer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Promptly after this regulation comes into force, the comptroller must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: ensure that every person is added to the register of well pump installers who, immediately before the date this regulation comes into force, was registered in the register of qualified well pump installers under the former regulation, and
issue an identification card to every person added to the register of well pump installers under paragraph (a) that identifies that person as a well pump installer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registered well driller or registered well pump installer must advise the comptroller in writing within 60 days after

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: any changes to the information included in the register in relation to the well driller or well pump installer, as the case may be, or
the person ceasing to work in Canada as a well driller or well pump installer, as the case may be.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The comptroller is not required to issue an identification card under section 9 or 11, as applicable, to a registered well driller or registered well pump installer if the registered well driller or registered well pump installer has not complied with subsection (1).

bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purposes of section 51 (3) [proof of qualifications and insurance] of the Act, the proof of qualifications that must be provided by a well driller or well pump installer is the identification card issued to the well driller or well pump installer by the comptroller under section 9 [registration and classification of well driller] or 11 [registration of well pump installer] of this regulation.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Qualifications for activities in relation to wells — well drillers

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of sections 48 (1) [definitions] and 49 (2) (b) (i) [restrictions on constructing or decommissioning wells and related activities] of the Act,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a registered well driller who is classified as a water well driller under section 9 (1) (a) (i) or (2) (a) [registration and classification of well driller] of this regulation is qualified in respect of constructing any class of well other than closed-loop geoexchange wells,
a registered well driller who is classified as a geoexchange driller under section 9 (1) (a) (ii) or (2) (a) of this regulation is qualified in respect of constructing closed-loop geoexchange wells,

a registered well driller who is classified as a geotechnical / environmental driller under section 9 (1) (a) (iii) or (2) (a) of this regulation is qualified in respect of constructing the following classes of well:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: monitoring wells;
geotechnical wells;
remediation wells, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: subject to section 15 of this regulation, a registered well driller is qualified in respect of decommissioning or deactivating any class of well.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of section 50 [restrictions respecting well pumps and flow tests] of the Act, registered well drillers referred to in subsection (1) (a) are qualified to carry out the activities under section 50 (1) (a) to (c) of the Act in respect of water supply wells, dewatering wells, injection wells and remediation wells.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Qualifications for activities in relation to artesian flow — well drillers

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of sections 52 (3) and (5) [controlling artesian flow during construction] and 53 (1) [controlling flowing artesian well] of the Act, a registered well driller is qualified to stop or control artesian flow in relation to a well if the well driller has competency in stopping or controlling artesian flow as a result of the well driller's training, experience, knowledge or skills.

Despite subsection (1), a registered well driller who is not qualified to stop or control artesian flow in relation to a well may undertake that activity if the well driller is supervised by another registered well driller, or a professional, who has competency in stopping or controlling artesian flow as a result of the training, experience, knowledge or skills of the other well driller or the professional, as the case may be.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Qualifications for activities in relation to wells — well pump installers
bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purposes of sections 48 (1) [definitions] and 49 (3) (e) [restrictions on constructing or decommissioning wells and related activities] of the Act, a well pump installer is qualified in respect of decommissioning or deactivating a well, other than a flowing artesian well.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: No restriction on who may decommission certain wells
bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purposes of section 49 (3) [restrictions on constructing or decommissioning wells and related activities] of the Act, any person may decommission the following wells, other than a flowing artesian well:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a well that has a depth of not more than 5 m;
an excavated well that has a depth of not more than 15 m.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Siting of water supply wells and permanent dewatering wells

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The person responsible for drilling a proposed water supply well or a proposed permanent dewatering well must site the proposed well so that the horizontal setback distance is not less than 15 m from any part of the proposed well to an existing water supply well, unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the existing water supply well is not in use and is not intended to be in use, or
the owner of the proposed well also owns the existing water supply well and only one well is proposed to be drilled.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The person responsible for drilling a proposed water supply well or proposed permanent dewatering well referred to in subsection (1) may, if the person responsible determines that it is not practicable to site the well as described in that subsection, site the proposed well with a horizontal setback distance from any part of the proposed well to an existing water supply well that is less than 15 m in accordance with alternative specifications that meet the requirements of subsection (3).
A proposed well under subsection (2) may be sited in accordance with alternative specifications for the siting of the proposed well if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a professional who has competency in the field of hydrogeology prepares the alternative specifications for the siting of the proposed well so that the existing uses of the existing water supply well will not be adversely affected,
the person responsible for drilling the well submits the alternative specifications to an engineer for acceptance by the engineer before the proposed well is drilled,
the engineer accepts the alternative specifications, with any terms and conditions the engineer may specify, and
the person responsible drills the water supply well, or permanent dewatering well, in accordance with

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the alternative specifications accepted by the engineer under paragraph (c), and
the terms and conditions, if any, specified by the engineer under that paragraph.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a water supply well or permanent dewatering well is drilled in accordance with alternative specifications under subsection (3), the person responsible for drilling the well must include the accepted alternative specifications, including the terms and conditions specified by the engineer, if any, with the well construction report required under section 76 [well construction reports submitted to both comptroller and well owner].

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Siting of recharge wells and injection wells

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Before a recharge well or injection well is constructed for the purpose of conveying urban runoff into the ground,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the owner of the proposed recharge well or injection well must retain a professional who has competency in the field of hydrogeology or geotechnical engineering to design the proposed well, and
the professional must

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: design the proposed well so that the proposed well does not cause a significant adverse impact on the quality of water in an aquifer or in another well that diverts water from the aquifer, and
specify the following distances in the design:

bcl:clause.bcl:text: a minimum horizontal distance between the proposed well and an existing water supply well;

a minimum vertical distance between the point of infiltration of the proposed well and the water table below to ensure that the point of infiltration of the proposed well is and will remain above the water table at all times.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the point of infiltration of treated water for a proposed recharge well or injection well is below the seasonal high water table, the professional, or the owner of the proposed recharge well or injection well, must submit the design described in subsection (1) to an engineer, who may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: accept the design, and may specify terms and conditions on the acceptance, and
determine whether the recharge well or injection well may be exempted from the minimum vertical distance specification described in subsection (1) (b) (ii) (B).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The person responsible for drilling a proposed recharge well or injection well must include the accepted design referred to in subsection (2), including the terms and conditions, if any, specified by the engineer with the well construction report if that report is required under section 76 [well construction reports submitted to both comptroller and well owner].
The owner of a proposed recharge well or injection well must ensure that the person responsible constructs the well in accordance with

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the design of the proposed recharge well or injection well made by the professional under subsection (1) (b), and
in the case of a proposed recharge well or injection well to which subsection (2) applies, the accepted design and the terms and conditions, if any, specified by the engineer under that subsection.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a recharge well or injection well must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: ensure that the professional prepares as-built drawings of the well, and
retain the design and any as-built drawings prepared by the professional until the well is decommissioned.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If a casing or liner is to be installed in a well in the course of drilling or altering the well, the person responsible for drilling or altering the well must install a casing or liner that is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: composed of new material or used material in like-new condition, and
strong enough to withstand the pressure or force exerted on the casing or liner during the installation of the casing or liner and the operation of the well.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Thermoplastic casings and liners for water supply wells
bcl:section.bcl:text: If a thermoplastic casing or thermoplastic liner is to be installed in a water supply well in the course of drilling or altering the well, the person responsible for drilling or altering the well must install a thermoplastic casing or thermoplastic liner that is approved or certified by one of the following for use for drinking water:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Canadian Standards Association;
Underwriters' Laboratories of Canada;
ASTM International;
NSF International.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The person responsible for drilling a well that has one or more casings must complete the well with an effective, permanent and continuous surface seal, as shown in Figures 1 and 2 of Schedule 5.

A surface seal required under subsection (1) must be installed in accordance with the applicable requirements of this Part to prevent the entry of any foreign matter from the surface of the ground into the well or the aquifer, if any, penetrated by the well.
A surface seal required under subsection (1) must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: installed in all annular spaces of the well,
not less than 2.54 cm thick, including the wall thickness of any surface casing left permanently in place, and
not less than

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: 1 m in length,
in the case of a water supply well, the length determined in accordance with section 23, or
in the case of a closed-loop geoexchange well, the entire length of the ground loop, in accordance with section 25 [sealing closed-loop geoexchange wells].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: All openings in the production casing of a well, including, without limitation, joints, lifting holes, perforations and pitless adapter holes, that are within the length of the surface seal must be made watertight with non-toxic materials.

The person responsible for drilling a water supply well that has one or more casings must, in addition to meeting the requirements under section 22, complete the water supply well with a surface seal that is not less than 5 m in length, unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the depth of the water supply well is insufficient to have a surface seal length of 5 m, in which case the surface seal must be the greatest possible length up to 5 m, or
the method of drilling the water supply well is by driving, in which case the surface seal must be not less than 1 m in length.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In addition to the requirements set out in subsection (1), if bedrock is encountered at or within 5 m of the surface of the ground in the circumstances described in subsection (1), other than those circumstances described in paragraph (b) of that subsection, the surface seal must extend to a minimum depth of 1 m into competent bedrock, as shown in Figure 3 of Schedule 5.
If an annular space is created during the installation of a surface casing, the person responsible for drilling the well must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: subject to paragraph (b), remove the surface casing and install the surface seal between the next outermost casing and the geological formation, or
if the surface casing cannot be removed,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: excavate the immediate area around the surface casing,

install sealant in the immediate area around the surface casing, as shown in Figure 2 of Schedule 5, to a length that is not less than 1 m and extends laterally from the surface casing to completely fill the excavated area, and

install sealant in the next outermost annular space, as shown in Figure 2 of Schedule 5, to a length that is not less than the minimum length required under section 22 (3) (c) [surface seal — general requirements].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (1) (b), the open annular space, if any, between multiple casings must be effectively capped with a well cap or sealed with a surface seal.

The person responsible for constructing a closed-loop geoexchange well must seal the closed-loop geoexchange well along the entire length of the ground loop, from the bottom upward, promptly after installing the ground loop.

The person responsible for converting an existing well into a closed-loop geoexchange well must seal the closed-loop geoexchange well the ground loop is in along the entire length of the ground loop, from the bottom upward, promptly after installing the ground loop.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A surface seal may extend to within 0.3 m of the surface of the ground to allow for up to 0.3 m of backfill materials above the surface seal, but the total length of the surface seal must not be less than the length required under section 22 (3) (c) [surface seal — general requirements].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an alteration to a well impairs the integrity of the existing surface seal, the person responsible for altering the well must ensure that the integrity of the surface seal is restored as soon as practicable.

If a structural change is made to the depth, diameter or screen assembly of a well that has a casing installed and that does not have a surface seal, the person responsible for making the structural change must install a surface seal that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is not less than 1 m in length or extends to bedrock, whichever is shorter, and
is not less than 2.54 cm thick.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Development, Well Yield Testing and Disinfection

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Development and screens — water supply wells

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this Division, alter does not include the installation of a surface seal.

The person responsible for drilling, altering or rehabilitating a water supply well must develop the water supply well in a manner that prevents the following during the development or operation of the water supply well:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: significant collapse of the surface of the ground around the water supply well;
damage to the surface seal of the water supply well.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The person responsible for drilling a water supply well into an unconsolidated aquifer, or altering a water supply well so that the well penetrates an unconsolidated aquifer, must equip the well with a screen assembly

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that is securely attached to the production casing, and
the screen component of which

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is composed of durable material having strength suited to the particular soil and water conditions encountered during drilling or alteration, and

has slot openings that are appropriately sized so that the depth of the well does not change as a result of sand or other unconsolidated material being drawn in during operation of the well or building up in the well.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A screen assembly is not required under subsection (3) if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the water supply well is an excavated well, or
the gravel or other unconsolidated material naturally exposed at the bottom of the production casing is coarse enough to allow the water supply well to be developed so that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the bottom of the production casing is stable, and
the depth of the well does not change as a result of sand or other unconsolidated material being drawn in during operation of the well or building up in the production casing.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Use of certain substances — water supply wells

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of section 59 (2) (d) [prohibition on introducing foreign matter into well] of the Act, drilling, altering, developing and rehabilitating are prescribed activities.

The person responsible for performing an activity referred to in subsection (1) may introduce acids, lubricants, bactericides or other similar substances into a water supply well in order to perform the activity in accordance with subsection (3).
If acids, lubricants, bactericides or other similar substances are used in connection with an activity under subsection (2), the person responsible for performing the activity must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: promptly after using the acids, lubricants, bactericides or other similar substances, remove groundwater from the water supply well until the remaining concentrations of acids, lubricants, bactericides and other similar substances in the remaining groundwater in the well would not prevent the use of the water supply well for its intended purpose, and

dispose of the groundwater removed from the water supply well in a manner that does not pose a threat to the aquatic ecosystem of a stream or an aquifer or to property, public safety or the environment.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The person responsible for drilling, altering, developing or rehabilitating a water supply well must, promptly after performing the activity, disinfect the groundwater in the well to destroy micro-organisms introduced by the activity.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The person responsible for drilling or altering a water supply well or a permanent dewatering well must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: conduct a well yield test, and
include the details of the well yield test in the well construction report required under section 76 [well construction reports submitted to both comptroller and well owner].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (1), a well yield test is not required if there is insufficient water in the well to conduct the test.

A well owner who is required to carry out a pumping test as part of an application for an authorization or by order of the comptroller, a water manager or an engineer must ensure that a professional who has competency in the field of hydrogeology

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: designs the test,
performs or directly supervises the test, and
interprets the results of the test.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A professional who has competency in the field of hydrogeology may install a temporary well pump to carry out a pumping test.
The person responsible for drilling or altering a well must ensure that the casing stick-up is continuous and extends a minimum of 0.3 m above

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the surface of the ground adjacent to the well, or
if applicable, the floor of the well sump, pump house or well pit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) does not apply in relation to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a geotechnical well,
a closed-loop geoexchange well,
a temporary dewatering well, or
a monitoring well drilled under the supervision of a professional who has competency in the field of hydrogeology or geotechnical engineering.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The person responsible for drilling or altering a well must ensure that thermoplastic casing at or above the surface of the ground is completely protected from damage and material breakdown.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Slope of surface of ground around wellhead
bcl:section.bcl:text: The person responsible for drilling or altering a well must slope the surface of the ground immediately around the wellhead to ensure that water does not pond around the wellhead or in the area disturbed during drilling.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Well pit restrictions — water supply wells

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Except as provided in this section, a person must not construct a well pit for the following activities:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: constructing a new water supply well;
adding a well pit to an existing water supply well that does not have an existing well pit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a water supply well that has an existing well pit is being altered, a person must either

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: remove the well pit, or
comply with subsections (3), (4), (5) and (6).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person may construct a well pit for a water supply well if the well pit is designed by a professional who has competency in the field of hydrogeology or geotechnical engineering to ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: water does not pond in the well pit, and
any water that enters the well pit is conveyed away in a manner that is not likely to cause an adverse impact on the quality of water in an aquifer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The construction of a well pit must be supervised by the professional who designs the well pit under subsection (3).
The owner of a water supply well with a well pit must ensure that the professional who designs the well pit under subsection (3) prepares as-built drawings of the well pit.
The professional who designs the well pit under subsection (3) must submit the design and as-built drawings to the owner and the comptroller within 90 days after the construction of the well pit.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Drainage away from wellhead — construction of wells in well sumps, pump houses or well pits

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The person responsible for constructing

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a well sump,
a pump house for a well, or
a well pit for a well

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: must ensure that the well sump, pump house or well pit is designed and constructed so that water entering the well sump, pump house or well pit is conveyed away from the wellhead.
Subsection (1) does not apply in relation to a well sump, pump house or well pit for a monitoring well if the well and the well sump, pump house or well pit are

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: designed by a professional who has competency in the field of hydrogeology or geotechnical engineering to prevent adverse impacts on the quality of water in an aquifer, and
constructed in accordance with that design.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsections (3) to (5), the person responsible for drilling or altering a well must, promptly on completing the drilling or alteration, securely attach to the top of the production casing a well cap that does all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prevents direct and unintended entry into the well of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: any water at the surface of the ground, including floodwater and ponded water, and
any foreign matter;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prevents persons or animals from entering the well;
prevents or minimizes the flow of water from a flowing artesian well.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A well cap required under subsection (1) must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: commercially manufactured, or
fabricated from durable material having strength suited to the location of the well cap and the local environmental conditions.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A steel plate welded to the top of the production casing may be used instead of a well cap on a well that is not yet in service.

The person responsible for drilling or altering a well that has an annular space between multiple casings must securely attach to the casings at the top of the annular space a permanent and watertight well cap that complies with subsection (2).
Subsection (1) does not apply in relation to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a geotechnical well,
a closed-loop geoexchange well, or
a water supply well equipped with a hand pump that meets the requirements of subsection (1) for a well cap.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Maintenance and attachment of well caps or steel plates

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A well owner must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a well cap that meets the applicable requirements of this Part remains securely attached to the top of the production casing or, if the well is not yet in service, a steel plate remains welded to the top of the production casing, and
the well cap or steel plate is maintained in good operating condition.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to section 42 [custom-designed well caps and well covers], if a well does not already have a well cap securely attached to the top of the production casing, the well owner must promptly and securely attach to the top of the production casing a well cap that meets the requirements of this Part.
A steel plate welded to the production casing may be used instead of a well cap on a well referred to in subsection (2) that is not yet in service.
Subsections (1) and (2) do not apply in relation to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a geotechnical well,
a closed-loop geoexchange well, or
a water supply well equipped with a hand pump that meets the requirements of section 38 (1) for a well cap.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (3), the person responsible for drilling or altering a well in which the top of the casing is below the surface of the ground must, in addition to complying with section 38 [well caps], promptly and securely install at or above the surface of the ground a well cover that does both of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prevents direct and unintended entry into the well of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: any water at the surface of the ground, including floodwater and ponded water, and
any foreign matter;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prevents persons or animals from entering the well.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A well cover required under subsection (1) must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: commercially manufactured, or
fabricated from durable material having strength suited to the location of the well cover and the local environmental conditions.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) does not apply in relation to a geotechnical well or a closed-loop geoexchange well.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Maintenance and installation of well covers

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a well that is completed below the surface of the ground, or in which the casing does not extend above the surface of the ground, must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a well cover that meets the applicable requirements of this Part remains securely installed, and
the well cover is maintained in good operating condition.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a well completed below the surface of the ground, or in which the casing does not extend above the surface of the ground, does not already have a well cover, the well owner must promptly and securely install at or above the surface of the ground a well cover that meets the applicable requirements of this Part.
Without limiting section 36 [well pit restrictions — water supply wells], this section does not apply in relation to a geotechnical well or a closed-loop geoexchange well.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Custom-designed well caps and well covers

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If it is not practicable for the owner of a well referred to in section 39 (2) [maintenance and attachment of well caps or steel plates] or 41 (2) to attach a well cap or install a well cover that meets the requirements of this Part, the well owner must engage a qualified well driller, qualified well pump installer or professional to design and attach an effective well cap or design and install an effective well cover.
For the purposes of subsection (1), a well cap is effective if it does all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prevents direct and unintended entry into the well of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: any water at the surface of the ground, including floodwater and ponded water, and
any foreign matter;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prevents persons or animals from entering the well;
stops or brings under control the flow of water from a flowing artesian well.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of subsection (1), a well cover is effective if the requirements of subsection (2) (a) and (b) are met.
The owner of a well must ensure that a well cap attached or well cover installed under this section is maintained in good operating condition.

bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Part, related works, in relation to a well pump, includes, without limitation, the pump motor, pump column, pitless adapter and sounding tube.
The person responsible for installing a well pump must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: install the well pump and related works so that there is no damage to or movement of the casing during the installation or operation of the well pump,
ensure that the well pump is protected by a liner if the well is unstable, and
install the well pump and related works in a manner that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: prevents the entry into the well of any foreign matter, and
allows the well, well pump and related works to be properly disinfected.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Pitless adapter installation, replacement or repair
bcl:section.bcl:text: The person responsible for installing, replacing or repairing a pitless adapter must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the pitless adapter is constructed with materials that will likely not have a significant adverse impact on water quality,
the pitless adapter is installed in a manner that will prevent corrosion of metal, and
the connection or seal between the pitless adapter and the production casing is watertight.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Thermoplastic liner, drop pipes and sounding tubes for water supply wells
bcl:section.bcl:text: If a thermoplastic liner, drop pipe or sounding tube is to be installed in a water supply well, the person responsible must ensure the thermoplastic liner, drop pipe or sounding tube is approved or certified by one of the following for use for drinking water:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Canadian Standards Association;
Underwriters' Laboratories of Canada;
ASTM International;
NSF International.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Devices to prevent flow of water back into well
bcl:section.bcl:text: The person responsible for installing a permanent well pump into a well must ensure that the well is equipped with a device that prevents the flow of water back into the well.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Sealing after installation of well pump or related works

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the installation of a well pump or related works in a well impairs the integrity of the existing surface seal, the person responsible for installing the well pump or related works must repair or replace the surface seal to meet the requirements of Division 3 [Surface Seals] of Part 3 [Well Construction].

If the installation of a well pump or related works in a well that does not have a surface seal creates a visible annular space between the outermost casing of the well and the surrounding geological formation, the person responsible for installing the well pump or related works must seal the annular space with sealant.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If the installation of a well pump or related works requires modification of the wellhead, the person responsible for the installation must ensure that, after the modification, the wellhead

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: meets, or continues to meet, the requirements of this regulation, and
remains compliant with the design of the professional referred to in section 36 (3) [well pit restrictions — water supply wells].

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Use of non-toxic lubricants and solvents

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of section 59 (2) (d) [prohibition on introducing foreign matter into well] of the Act, the activity of installing, maintaining or repairing a well pump is a prescribed activity.
The person responsible for performing an activity referred to in subsection (1) may use a lubricant or solvent for the activity if the lubricant or solvent is non-toxic.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Hand pumps in water supply wells

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The person responsible for installing a hand pump in a water supply well must ensure that the hand pump is installed so that it meets the requirements of section 38 (1) [well caps] that apply in respect of a well cap.

If a water supply well is equipped with a hand pump that is not installed as described in subsection (1), the owner of the water supply well must ensure that the hand pump is upgraded or replaced before March 1, 2018 so as to comply with that subsection.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Disinfection of water supply wells after well pump activities
bcl:section.bcl:text: The person responsible, in respect of a water supply well, for installing a permanent well pump or removing a temporary well pump must disinfect the groundwater in the well to destroy any micro-organisms introduced by that activity.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Attachment of well identification plates by person responsible for drilling or alteration

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a well identification plate is required for a well under column 3 of the table in Schedule 6, the person responsible for drilling the well must, promptly on completing the drilling, securely attach to the well, in accordance with section 55 [well identification plate attachment], a well identification plate that has been obtained from the comptroller.

The person responsible for altering a well that does not have a well identification plate as required under column 3 of the table in Schedule 6 must, promptly on completing the alteration, securely attach to the well, in accordance with section 55, a well identification plate that has been obtained from the comptroller.

The person responsible referred to in subsection (1) or (2) must report the well identification in the well construction report made under section 76 [well construction reports submitted to both comptroller and well owner].

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Attachment of well identification plates by owner of well supplying water supply system

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a well drilled for the purpose of supplying a water supply system must, if a well identification plate has not already been attached to the well, promptly and securely attach to the well, in accordance with section 55, a well identification plate that has been obtained from the comptroller.

As soon as practicable after attaching a well identification plate, the well identification must be reported in a well identification report in accordance with section 75 [well identification reports by owner of well supplying water supply system].
A well identification plate required under this Part must be securely attached to the casing, well cap or well cover of the well so that the well identification number is plainly visible.

If it is not possible to securely attach the well identification plate to the casing, well cap or well cover, the well identification plate may be securely attached to any of the following so that the well identification number is plainly visible:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the discharge pipe;
the pump motor housing;
the stand at the top of the well;
the pump house;
a nearby post.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If 2 or more wells are contained in a single protective casing, each of those wells must have a well identification plate.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Protection and replacement of well identification plates

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a well that is required under section 53 [attachment of well identification plates by person responsible for drilling or alteration] or 54 [attachment of well identification plates by owner of well supplying water supply system] to have a well identification plate attached must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: protect the well identification plate from any physical damage,
ensure that the well identification plate is promptly attached and remains securely attached in accordance with section 55 so that the well identification number remains plainly visible, and
if the well identification plate is missing or damaged,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: report the loss or damage to the comptroller within 30 days after discovering the loss or damage, and
request the comptroller to supply a replacement well identification plate.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a replacement well identification plate is supplied by the comptroller, the well owner must ensure that the well identification plate is promptly attached and remains securely attached in accordance with section 55.

bcl:section.bcl:text: This Part applies in relation to a well whether or not the well is in use, in service or deactivated, but does not apply in relation to a well that has been decommissioned in accordance with this regulation.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: General operating requirements for well and area around wellhead

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a well must ensure the following in respect of the operation of a well and wellhead:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the surface of the ground immediately around the wellhead remains sloped so that water does not pond around the wellhead;
the well and the area immediately around the wellhead are maintained in a manner that prevents the entry into the well of any foreign matter;
any repairs to the well or wellhead are promptly undertaken when required to ensure that the well and wellhead are maintained in good operating condition.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a well must ensure the following in respect of a well and wellhead:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: access to the well and wellhead is maintained for inspections undertaken in accordance with section 89 [right of access to land and premises by authorized persons] of the Act;
the area immediately around the wellhead is kept clear of all obstructions, including vegetation, that might interfere with

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the alteration, repair, maintenance or inspection of the well, or
the alteration, repair, maintenance, replacement, removal or inspection of works.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Drainage away from wellhead — maintenance of wells in well sumps, pump houses or well pits
bcl:section.bcl:text: The owner of a well that is in a well sump, pump house or well pit must ensure that the well sump, pump house or well pit is maintained in a manner so that any water entering the well sump, pump house or well pit is conveyed away from the wellhead.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Operation of water supply wells and permanent dewatering wells with alternative specifications
bcl:section.bcl:text: The owner of a water supply well or permanent dewatering well that is drilled in accordance with alternative specifications under section 18 (3) [siting of water supply wells and permanent dewatering wells] must ensure that the well is completed, equipped, operated and maintained in accordance with the accepted alternative specifications, including any terms and conditions specified by the engineer.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Conveyance of urban runoff — recharge wells and injection wells
bcl:section.bcl:text: The owner of a recharge well or injection well constructed for the purpose of conveying urban runoff into the ground must ensure that the recharge well or injection well is completed, equipped, operated and maintained

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in accordance with the design referred to in section 19 (1) [siting of recharge wells and injection wells] and the applicable terms and conditions, if any, and
so that the recharge well or injection well does not cause a significant adverse impact on the quality of water in an aquifer or in another well that diverts water from the aquifer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not leave any foreign matter, store any foreign matter or allow any foreign matter to accumulate within 3 m of the wellhead of a water supply well.
A person must ensure that any foreign matter that the person leaves, stores or allows to accumulate beyond the 3 m referred to in subsection (1) does not travel to within that 3 m.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Protection of water supply system wells from entry of foreign matter and physical damage
bcl:section.bcl:text: The owner of a well constructed or altered for the purpose of supplying a water supply system must ensure that the well is completed, equipped and maintained in a manner that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prevents any foreign matter from entering from the surface of the ground into the well, either directly into the top of the well or through an annular space, and
protects the well and wellhead from physical damage due to flood debris, ice or erosion.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a well that has a surface seal must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the integrity of the surface seal is maintained, and
in the case of a closed-loop geoexchange well, any visible openings in the well are sealed with sealant.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a visible annular space appears around the outermost casing of a well, the owner of the well must ensure that the visible annular space is sealed with sealant.
The owner of a well to which section 33 [casing stick-up] applies must ensure that the production casing

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is maintained in a manner that ensures that the production casing remains continuous and the casing stick-up extends a minimum of 0.3 m above

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the surface of the ground adjacent to the well, or
the floor of the well sump, pump house or well pit, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if damaged, is repaired or replaced with production casing that meets the requirements of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: section 20 [casings and liners — general requirements],
section 21 [thermoplastic casings and liners for water supply wells], if applicable, and
section 34 [protection of thermoplastic casings], if applicable.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a well must ensure that thermoplastic casing used in the well remains protected from damage and material breakdown.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Additional requirements — stopping or controlling artesian flow
bcl:section.bcl:text: The person responsible for stopping or controlling artesian flow of a well under section 52 (7) [controlling artesian flow during construction] of the Act must, in addition to the requirements of the Act,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: configure the wellhead or equip the well with a device that prevents the flow of water back into the well, and

measure the shut-in pressure or static water level and record that measurement on the well construction report required under section 76 [well construction reports submitted to both comptroller and well owner] of this regulation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The professional who, in relation to a flowing artesian well, prepares a report for the purposes of section 52 (6) [controlling artesian flow during construction] of the Act must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: have competency in the field of hydrogeology or geotechnical engineering,
assess the artesian flow conditions of the flowing artesian well, and
record the assessment of the artesian flow conditions.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A report referred to in subsection (1), in relation to a flowing artesian well, must include the information set out in Schedule 1 and be submitted as soon as practicable after the assessment of the artesian flow conditions.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Maintenance of equipment installed to control artesian flow
bcl:section.bcl:text: The owner of a flowing artesian well must ensure that equipment installed to control the artesian flow

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is maintained in a manner that allows the artesian flow to be controlled and the flow of water back into the well to be prevented,
is protected from damage caused by freezing conditions,
is not removed from the well except for the purpose of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: inspecting, repairing or replacing the equipment, or
an activity relating to the well that requires the temporary removal of the equipment, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if removed for a purpose described in paragraph (c), is replaced promptly.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (3), for the purposes of section 56 (2) (a) [decommissioning or deactivating well] of the Act, the prescribed period for a well to be considered to be not in service is 5 years.
Subject to subsection (3), for the purposes of section 56 (4) of the Act, the prescribed period for a deactivated well to be considered to be not in service is 5 years.

The prescribed periods set out in subsections (1) and (2) do not apply in the case of a flowing artesian well that is managed in accordance with section 52 (6) [controlling artesian flow during construction] or 53 (3) [controlling flowing artesian well] of the Act.

If a flowing artesian well is managed in accordance with section 52 (6) or 53 (3) of the Act, the requirements of this Part do not apply in respect of the well until it is possible to deactivate or decommission the well in accordance with the recommendations of a professional, as accepted by an engineer.
The person responsible for deactivating a water supply well, an injection well, a dewatering well or a remediation well must take the well pump out of operation by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: shutting off the power supply to the well pump, or
removing or disconnecting the manual pump handle.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In the case of a flowing artesian well, the person responsible for deactivating the well must, in addition to complying with subsection (1),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prevent any flow of water back into the well,
stop any artesian flow through the casing, and
prevent any leakage of the artesian flow at the surface of the ground or into another aquifer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The person responsible for deactivating a recharge well must install equipment that prevents water, contaminants and foreign matter from entering the well through the top of the well.
The person responsible for deactivating a monitoring well must take out of operation any equipment used for monitoring.
The person responsible for deactivating a closed-loop geoexchange well must take out of operation any equipment used for the geoexchange system.
Subject to section 72, the person responsible for decommissioning a well must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if practicable, remove from the well the well pump and all other equipment and instrumentation,
fill the well throughout its depth with layers of sealant and backfill materials in a manner that precludes any lengthwise movement of liquids

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: within the well,
in any visible annular space between the outer casing and the surrounding geological formation, and
between casings,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: seal off all known aquifers and known water-bearing zones within an aquifer, as shown in Figure 4 of Schedule 5, to prevent mixing of groundwater from different aquifers or different water-bearing zones within an aquifer,

subject to paragraph (e), subsection (5) of this section and section 74 (2), install a closure plug that is at least 1 m in length and, if the depth of the well is insufficient to have a closure plug length of 1 m, the greatest possible length up to 1 m, and

if the well is a water supply well, or a well that was used at any time as a water supply well, install a closure plug that, subject to subsection (5), is not less than 5 m in length and, if the depth of the water supply well is insufficient to have a closure plug length of 5 m, the greatest possible length up to 5 m.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The person responsible for decommissioning a well may leave casings in place.
If there is a potential for entry of liquids into a well, the person responsible for decommissioning the well must fill any entry points or openings with sealant.
The person responsible for decommissioning a well must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the uncased portion of the well has layers of sealant, as shown in Figure 4 of Schedule 5, that are

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: at least 1 m in length, and
separated by not more than 6 m of backfill materials, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all sealant is placed in the well in a manner that ensures the physical integrity and continuity of the seal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A closure plug may extend to within 0.3 m of the surface of the ground to allow for up to 0.3 m of backfill materials above the closure plug, but the total length of the closure plug must not be less than the length required under subsection (1) (d) or (e), as applicable.

If a well that is being decommissioned is a closed-loop geoexchange well, the person responsible for decommissioning the well must remove the circulation fluids from the ground loops in the closed-loop geoexchange system.
If a well that is being decommissioned is a flowing artesian well, the person responsible for decommissioning the well must, in addition to complying with this section,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: stop the artesian flow through the casing, and
prevent any leakage of the artesian flow at the surface of the ground or into another aquifer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the person responsible for decommissioning a well determines, before decommissioning the well, that it is not practicable to comply with section 71 (1) (b), (d) or (e), (4) or (5), the person may decommission the well in accordance with alternative specifications prepared by a professional under subsection (2) of this section.
A well referred to in subsection (1) may be decommissioned in accordance with alternative specifications in respect of section 71 (1) (b), (d) or (e), (4) or (5) if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a professional who has competency in the field of hydrogeology or geotechnical engineering prepares alternative specifications for the decommissioning of the well that ensure that isolated groundwater from different aquifers, or from different water-bearing zones within an aquifer, remain isolated,
the person responsible for decommissioning the well submits the alternative specifications to an engineer for acceptance by the engineer before the well is decommissioned,
the engineer accepts in writing the alternative specifications, with any terms and conditions that the engineer may specify, and
the person responsible decommissions the well in accordance with the alternative specifications accepted by the engineer under paragraph (c) and any terms and conditions specified by the engineer.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The owner of a temporary well must ensure that, within 90 days after drilling is completed, the temporary well is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: decommissioned in accordance with section 71 [requirements for decommissioning wells] or 72, as applicable, or
made into a permanent well that meets the standards and requirements of the Act and this regulation that apply to a permanent well of the applicable class.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a borehole must ensure that, within 30 days after drilling is completed, the borehole is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: decommissioned in accordance with section 71 [requirements for decommissioning wells] or 72 [alternative specifications for decommissioning wells], as applicable, or
made into a temporary or permanent well that meets the standards and requirements of the Act and this regulation that apply to a temporary or permanent well of the applicable class.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a test pit must ensure that, within 30 days after excavation is completed, the test pit is decommissioned by backfilling with backfill materials.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Well identification reports by owner of well supplying water supply system
bcl:section.bcl:text: The owner of a well that supplies a water supply system who attaches a well identification plate in accordance with section 54 [attachment of well identification plates by owner of well supplying water supply system] must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: complete a well identification report in the form specified by the comptroller that includes the information set out in Schedule 2, and
submit to the comptroller, in the manner specified by the comptroller, a copy of the well identification report within 90 days after attaching the well identification plate.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Well construction reports submitted to both comptroller and well owner
bcl:section.bcl:text: If a well construction report must be completed under column 4 of the table in Schedule 6 and must be submitted to both the comptroller and the well owner under column 6 of that table in respect of a class of well, the person responsible for drilling or altering a well in that class must do all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: complete a well construction report, in the form specified by the comptroller, that includes the information set out in Schedule 3;
submit a copy of the well construction report, within 90 days after completing the drilling or alteration,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: to the comptroller in the manner specified by the comptroller, and
to the well owner;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: retain the well construction report for at least 10 years.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Well construction reports submitted to well owner only
bcl:section.bcl:text: If a well construction report must be completed under column 4 of the table in Schedule 6 and must be submitted to only the well owner under column 6 of that table in respect of a class of well, the person responsible for drilling or altering a well in that class must do all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: complete a well construction report, in the form specified by the comptroller, that includes the information set out in Schedule 3;
submit a copy of the well construction report, within 90 days after completing the drilling or alteration, to the well owner;
retain the well construction report for at least 10 years.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Well decommission reports submitted to both comptroller and well owner
bcl:section.bcl:text: If a well decommission report must be completed under column 5 of the table in Schedule 6 and must be submitted to both the comptroller and the well owner under column 6 of that table in respect of a class of well, the person responsible for decommissioning a well in that class must do all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: complete a well decommission report, in the form specified by the comptroller, that includes the information set out in Schedule 4;
submit a copy of the well decommission report, within 90 days after decommissioning the well,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: to the comptroller in the manner specified by the comptroller, together with the well identification plate, if applicable, and
to the well owner;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: retain the well decommission report for at least 10 years.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Well decommission reports submitted to well owner only
bcl:section.bcl:text: If a well decommission report must be completed under column 5 of the table in Schedule 6 and must be submitted only to the well owner under column 6 of that table in respect of a class of well, the person responsible for decommissioning a well in that class must do all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: complete a well decommission report, in the form specified by the comptroller, that includes the information set out in Schedule 4;
submit a copy of the well decommission report, within 90 days after decommissioning the well, to the well owner;
retain the well decommission report for at least 10 years.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Well decommission reports for flowing artesian wells
bcl:section.bcl:text: If a well that is decommissioned in accordance with section 71 [requirements for decommissioning wells] or 72 [alternative specifications for decommissioning wells] is a flowing artesian well, or if artesian flow is encountered during the decommissioning of a well, the person responsible for decommissioning the well must complete and submit a well decommission report to both the comptroller and the owner of the well in accordance with section 78 [well decommission reports submitted to both comptroller and well owner].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of section 116 (1) [records and reporting] of the Act, the prescribed period during which the owner of a well must keep information and records under this section is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of information and records described in subsection (2) of this section, until the well is decommissioned, and
in the case of information and records described in subsection (3) of this section, until 10 years after the well is decommissioned.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of section 116 (1) (b) of the Act, the owner of a well must keep, for the period set out in subsection (1) (a), the following information and records:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: every well identification report and well construction report required in respect of the well;
a report on every flow test conducted in respect of the well;
if the well is an injection well, every as-built drawing, if any, prepared under section 19 (5) (a) [siting of recharge wells and injection wells] of this regulation;
if the well is in a well pit, every as-built drawing, if any, prepared under section 36 (5) [well pit restrictions — water supply wells] of this regulation.
